titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I began this morning the Translation of the third Olynthiac of Demosthenes— And finished the reading of Leland’s Translation— Called on Mrs: Newton, who at the end of her quarter proposes to leave my house— I did not intend to have gone out of town this day, but Mr: T. Greenleaf jr came in purposely from Quincy, with a Chaise for me, and I therefore went out, and took George with me.

2. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day. Mr: Beale was part of the Evening at my father’s— The leisure part of the day I employed upon researches respecting the Greek Language, and found a book of Viger, edited and improved by Hogeveen; and further improved by Zeunius, which will furnish me some new lights in my pursuit— I read also the preface to my father’s excellent edition of Plutarch’s lives; which contains some good observations on the means of acquiring the Greek.

3. Mrs: T. B. Adams came with me in to Boston, and we brought in George— I found my wife confined to her bed, with a high fever; which continued the whole day— She is weaning her youngest child, Charles, and her illness proceeds from the abundance of his provisions which remain unbestowed. She was at Night a little better. This afternoon five Gentlemen as a Committee from all the towns in this District called upon me to request that I would consent to be held up as their Candidate—to the approaching election for Congress. They were Dr: Townsend, and Mr: Tilden of Boston, Mr: Harris of Charlestown— The two other Gentlemen I did not know— I declined however acceding to their request, which they urged untill my perseverance in declining appeared offensive, and they left me, with apparent dissatisfaction— I had felt a perfect confidence from what had passed between me and Mr: Bacon first, and Blake afterwards, that I should have avoided this perplexity— I pray that I may have the means of being conducted through it without a violation of any duty to the public Service or to private friendship.

div.p: 4. My wife continues still quite unwell.— I met this morning Mr: Tilden, who told me the Gentlemen that came with him yesterday, and whom I did not know were Mr: Fearing of Hingham, and Mr: Hall of Malden— He said they had adjourned a fortnight, in the hope that I would reconsider, my determination express’d to them yesterday— And that Mr: Austin and Mr: Prince were added to the Committee.— This afternoon, I prepared my lecture for next Friday— I begin my course over again, making very little alteration upon that formerly read— In the Evening I read the 3d: Book of W. Scott’s Marmion.

div.p: 5. Mr: Pelham brought me a manuscript to examine; as did also Mr: Biggs, the remainder of his History of Miranda’s expedition— This afternoon I began the sketch of a lecture upon Oratory— This part of my course I intend to commence, with a critical account and examination of Demosthenes.— Evening at the Club at Mr: Smith’s— Mrs: Adams is still confined to her chamber.

6. I read this morning at my Office Lord Holland’s Preface to Mr: Fox’s history; with which I am well pleased— At the Insurance Office, on the business of their Cause— Afternoon and Evening teaching George, and reading Scott’s Marmion. I have too much set aside Demosthenes— Laborious idleness is the great sin of my life.

7. I walked to Cambridge this morning, and commenced anew my course of Lectures. Read the first with some slight alterations— Pass’d the remainder of the forenoon at the Library— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— He was absent from home; at Plymouth.— Attended the Declamation at 2. after which I walked home— Dr: Townsend called upon me again; to say that the Committee of which he was chairman proposed to call once more on me, and express their wishes that I would still consent to stand their candidate at the next Election. I told him that although I should be glad to see the Gentlemen personally, I should hope they would not take the trouble to call again on that subject— That the more I reflected upon it, the more I was confirmed in my own resolution— I mentioned to him my attachment to the present member—that I could find no proper motive sufficiently strong in my own mind to justify the sacrifice of that sentiment, which I must make by consenting to have my name held up in opposition to his; even were I certain of success. That I would not be inattentive or inactive to the Cause, which I believe to be that of the Country; but in the present instance, could not prevail upon myself to stand for the Election— He left me seemingly satisfied with my reasons, though not with my determination— Evening at home reading Marmion, and teaching George.

8. Mr: James Prince, an additional member of the Republican Committee called upon me this morning, and renewed the solicitations, which I had declined to comply with— I still adhered however to my purpose, in the propriety of which I find myself daily more strongly confirmed.— Mr: De Grand spent the Evening with me.

9. My brother came in from Dedham last Evening, and took his wife out with him to Quincy this morning.— I heard Dr: Eliot in the first, and Mr: S. Thacher, the librarian of the College in the latter part of the day— Catherine pass’d the Evening at Mr: Foster’s— Mrs: Adams read to me Tillotson’s Sermons 145 and 146. On the Goodness of God. The rest of the day I was employed in my own and George’s studies.

10. Mr: Benjamin Austin this morning called at my Office, and in a long conversation urged me again to permit my name to be held up as the candidate for this district at the approaching election— Two other members of the Committee also called at my house this afternoon for the same purpose— I think a Mr: Rhodes and Mr:I persevered however in my determination to the last.— In proportion as the anxious importunities of these persons have been repeated, my own anxiety, to discharge faithfully all my duties has encreased upon me. The first and the last impression upon my mind has been, that I ought not to sacrifice the obligations of private friendship, by suffering myself to be put up in opposition to Mr: Quincy. The other considerations, which in the first instance would have disinclined me to consent, I should have given up to the earnestness, and the propriety with which I have been entreated, merely not to decline an election, if my name should be announced. I believe the election would be carried.— At any rate; I should carry all but a majority, if not a complete one. At any rate my personal feelings would be gratified by the strength of the support I should receive. My personal importance would be raised, in the estimation of both parties, and I am not unaware that my resolution on this occasion, will have the contrary effect upon both— All this however I must be willing to endure— I can find no difficulty in disposing of arguments the power of which centres in myself— The subject has been presented to me by my own feelings and by others in a more fascinating form— That the moment is critical— That a patriotic Citizen ought not to withhold himself from the public Service, and the wishes of his fellow-citizens— That private friendship must be made subordinate to the public welfare— And that by merely being inactive, and doing nothing either to encourage or to discountenance the nomination, I should not
violate any duty of friendship, since rival candidates may still remain cordial friends— This reasoning I have found it most arduous to resist— I do believe my services to be a right of my Country to claim— But so are Quincy’s—and I cannot bring myself to that pitch of self-imagined importance, as to suppose that I am bound to seek the means of public service, by acceding to an attempt at edging him out of it— The representation of this District is not the hinge upon which the destinies of this Nation will turn, nor is Quincy a man who will lend himself to the destructive projects of the present leaders of the federal party.— Upon the whole, I feel satisfied with my own decision in this case— Its event is in wiser hands than mine— I read this day Judge Davis’s opinion upon the embargo question— Returned it this Evening to Mr: Shaw at his office— Mrs: Adams read to me part of the Introductory chapter to Fox’s history. Catherine pass’d the Evening, at Mr: Joy’s.

11. Mr: Quincy called upon me this morning; with papers relative to the conveyance of land from the Neponset Bridge proprietors to him, and also to the conveyance of a privilege of pasturing Cattle in the Quincy burying yard, from him and me to the inhabitants of the Town— We executed the latter— But I keep the papers in the other case to look into the Charter of the Company, and the deed of the land to them— I called also upon Mr: Gore, respecting a pew at Mr: Emerson’s meeting-house, which has been assigned to him, and which I wish to hire— He will ascertain whether it is yet sold; and if not, will let me have it— Spent the Evening with Catherine at Dr: Welsh’s—where there was a small family party. On the whole this has been a day of little, but some useful occupation.

12. Mr: and Mrs: Boylston called to see us this morning— I was engaged in packing and sending away a box of books for the library of Congress; which I ship’d in a vessel to sail this afternoon— The remainder of the day I was engaged with George; untill Evening— I walk’d in the Mall, successively with Mr: E. Gray, and Mr: J. Gardner, whom I met there— Then attended the club at Dr: Spooner’s— It was not very full, but, Sir Isaac Coffin and Mr: Wilson of Philadelphia were there.

13. Day employed as usual, but as the Nights lengthen, I find the time of my necessary inactivity increase. From dinner time untill dark, I devote almost entirely to George, when there is no public school— This Evening we attended a Ball at Mr: Foster’s, our next neighbour. Mrs: Adams and myself left the Company about 10.— Mr: Otis and Mr: Callender were there; with their Ladies— The remainder of the Company were all young people; and among them several scholars from College.

div.p: 14. I walked to and from Cambridge— Read my second Lecture— Called on the President to enquire with regard to changing the hour of reading my lecture to the afternoon— Attended the chemical Lecture of Dr: Dexter— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Attended the Declamation at 2. Only four speakers— Heard afterwards the performances for the exhibition next week. In the Evening at home, I finished reading Scott’s Marmion— Mr: S. A. Otis called on me to say he should go, for Washington next Tuesday.

15. Saw Mr: Dexter and Mr: Hall, and also Mr: Welles, at the Insurance Office, on the business of their suit in the Supreme Court of the State— It was finally agreed that it would be best to settle it on terms proposed by Mr: Higginson— The rest of the morning I was occupied, in preparing papers to be sent to Washington by the mail, and by Mr: Otis— Afternoon, teaching George— Evening, walking with Mr: J. Gardner, and reading Jones’s Astronomical Essays— I finished this morning the Translation of the third Olynthiac of Demosthenes.

16. Mr: Cutts with his family, and Mr: Cook and his Lady called this morning, on their way to Washington— Mr: Cook came in for a few minutes— They are going to attend the Session of Congress, which is to commence, the first Monday in next Month.— I heard Mr: Whitney of Quincy, morning and afternoon— Catherine went after dinner. Read this Evening Tillotson’s Sermons 147 and 148.— On the Mercy and Patience of God— Began this morning the Translation of Demosthenes’s Oration for the Crown— A work which I fear I shall not have patience to accomplish.

17. I called this morning on Mr: Buckminster, and borrowed of him, his first volume of Reiske’s edition of the Greek Orators, and the volume of Indices to Demosthenes— The Commentary and notes is scattered through so many volumes that I did not take them.— Mr: B. Joy spoke to me about going to Washington next February, for the Georgia-Land Company—on a Cause which they have before the Supreme Court— But nothing determinate was done— I read Chapman’s observations on the Commentary bearing the name of Ulpian, on the Orations of Demosthenes—in Mountenay’s Edition. Afternoon & Evening, teaching George— Study shortens time, and progress in it is inconceivably slow— Called this Evening on Mr: S. A. Otis.

18. Attended this morning the Exhibition at Cambridge— Mrs: Adams and Catherine went with me— The performances were very good.— We dined with the two sons of Mr: Parkman; who was himself there with his family, and a number of his friends— Immediately after dinner we returned to Boston— Mr: De Grand pass’d the Evening with us.

19. Day spent at my Office and at home— Finished reading Chapman’s observations on the Commentary of Ulpian. There is in them much erudition, and some critical sagacity— Their object is to prove from internal evidence that the Commentary could not be the work of Ulpian of Antioch; but must be ascribed to a later writer and a Roman— Mr: Quincy was at my Office this morning— Attended Club this Evening at Dr: Warren’s. It was fully attended— Dr: Coney and Mr: Newcomb of Greenfield were there.— I had walk’d with Mr: J. Gardner in the Mall.

20. I executed the deed of Land from the Neponset Bridge proprietors to Mr: Quincy.— Met Dr Eustis in the Street, and went with him to his house where I had half an hours conversation with him on the State of Affairs— He is ashamed of certain leaders in his own party— Dissatisfied with the General Government— Bitter against the federalists; eager for another state of things; but not knowing how to produce it— Afternoon chiefly employed in teaching George— Read part of Leland’s life of Philip of Macedon. My wife was unwell in the Evening.

div.p: 21. Walk’d to and from Cambridge, and read my third Lecture— Pass’d a couple of hours in the Library; dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s. Called at President Webber’s, and he agreed to the alteration of the hour for delivering my lecture; from 10 in the morning to 3. in the afternoon— In the Evening I was very much fatigued, having been up the whole night with my wife who was extremely ill. Mr: Everett pass’d the Evening with us.

22. The Circuit Court of the United States is sitting in this town; which I attended during part of the Morning. My brother came in from Quincy, and dined with us. In the afternoon I went with him out to Quincy, taking George— We had a storm of rain the whole way.

23. Heard Mr: Allyn of Duxbury, in the morning; but accidentally failed of hearing him in the afternoon. The remainder of the day I employed in my own Greek studies, and the French studies of my son George.— I read some of the letters in Dalrymple’s Memoirs, and also part of Plutarch’s life of Demosthenes.

24. Returned to Boston this morning, with George in the Stage— My brother and his wife, and Louisa Smith also came in. We had a day of much bustle and preparation, for a Ball in the Evening.— We had a company of about sixty persons; and by using the house next to that in which we dwell, which has been empty ever since Mr: Gardner left it, we found sufficient accommodation for them— They danced untill about 1. O’Clock in the morning, when the party broke up.

25. Dissipation always leaves dregs behind it.— This has been a day of idleness to me— I find it impossible to recover immediately the power of application— My neighbour Mr: Foster called this morning to inform me of the news that France had declared War against the United States— At the Insurance Office, I found the source of the report, which without being absolutely certain, has strong foundations of probability— Saw Mr: Quincy there, and he called to take leave of me this afternoon— He goes for Washington to-morrow Morning— We made a short Evening of it at home, to balance for the long one of yesterday.

26. Mr: B. Joy spoke to me again this day at the Insurance Office, on the proposal to go to Washington, for the Mississippi land Company, to argue the question before the Supreme Court of the United States— I am to give him an answer in two or three days— The Club were this Evening at my house; and the attendance was general— Mr: Gray, Mr: Smith, Dr: Eliot and Dr: Howard, were not here— Louisa Smith returned to Quincy.— Also my brother & his wife.

27. My Mother came into town this morning with Susan Adams, and brought in our son John, who has been nearly four months at my father’s, on account of his health— He is still weak and sickly; but better than when he went out. My Mother was again here this afternoon, and returned home to Quincy— Mr: Everett and Mr: Leonard Foster pass’d the Evening with us, and supp’d— I resumed Demosthenes on the Crown, and George’s lessons.

div.p: 28. On rising this morning I found the ground covered with snow, and the storm still continuing— It prevented me from going to Cambridge at the usual hour— It snow’d untill about 11. in the forenoon, and then clearing away, I walk’d to Cambridge, and attended the declamation at 2. O’Clock— There was the full number of Speakers— I gave notice that my lectures during the remainder of the term would be read at 3. in the afternoon. Walk’d home; and read in the Evening Leland’s life of Philip, and something of Southey’s Thalaba.

29. Attended a short time this morning at the Circuit Court, which is still in Session— The Carriage was sent in for us from Quincy, and I went out with my wife and George to my father’s this afternoon— He had not returned from dining with the agricultural Society at Mr: Lowell’s in Roxbury.— The War news proves to have been a false alarm.

30. Heard Mr: Green of Malden, morning and afternoon— Gave an hour to George’s lesson, and the remainder of day light employed in reading the Greek Testament. As I am compell’d in a great measure to abandon reading by candle-light for the sake of my eyes, my time of possible application at this season of the year is very much shortened.

31. We returned to Boston this morning. I saw Mr: B. Joy at the Insurance-Office; and told him the terms upon which I would go to Washington, upon the business he had mentioned to me. He said they could not agree to those terms, and urged me to accept of easier proposals— I promised to consider them; and give my answer to-morrow or Wednesday— But I see no reason for retreating.— Coll: Welles in a joke told me he heard they were going to make me Governor— (By they he meant the Republican party) upon which I told him in the same manner, that I should not expect his vote for me— B. Russell asked me to attend a federal Caucus, to promote the Election of Mr: Quincy; who he understood was my friend— I told him Mr: Quincy was my very good friend— But that if I attended the Caucus I hoped he (Russell) would not publish in his paper that I attended it without invitation; or that I voted at it for myself— Like the lies published last Winter on my attending Bradley’s Caucus— I called this Evening at Mr: Shaw’s Office, to look at the papers mentioned to me by Mr: Joy, but found them too voluminous to be read before they are printed.— Mr: Ripley was here this afternoon.

Day. I rise usually with the Sun—read four chapters of the Greek Testament, and if I have any time left, a little of Demosthenes— Breakfast between 9 and 10. pass a couple of hours at my Office; and sometimes an hour at the Insurance Office, reading newspapers— Home to dinner; between 2 and 3. After dinner untill dark reading again Demosthenes, or teaching George, the french language— Walk near an hour in the Mall— Remainder of the Evening sometimes in company abroad— Sometimes with company at home— Sometimes reading to the Ladies or hearing them read untill 9. or 10. Supper— Bed about 11— On Friday’s I spent the principal part of the day at Quincy; and often from Saturday untill Monday at Quincy— Here is too much Time given to Society— Too much to passive Study—and too little to action of any kind.
